title: When can you advise creditors / collectors of bankruptcy? Do you have to wait until it is discharged to start telling them?
question: I am in the midst of the bankruptcy intake process, putting all vendors into the Bankruptcy document entry, however I need to know when I can start to advise collectors that I am filing.
question_tags: Child support,Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt
answers: You can inform the collectors you are planning to file bankruptcy right away. Unfortunately, unless you have a lawyer they may not believe you. Once you actually file you will have a case number which is the proof they want to see.

You need an attorney to assist and represent you is ALL of our advice and you asking that questions means you have not done so. Its important to do it right the first time. The court notifies the creditors in your matrix the day the case is filed by mail or electronically! But other issues and facts can gravely affect your case so I will point those out next for you. But telling a creditor is ok..maybe...sometimes there are creditors we advise you NOT to tell you are filing..and hence the reason to sit down with an experienced attorney.

You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an
attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping
everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the
exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523
(Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and
presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so
you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!
Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your
state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but
your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity
thereof!
Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your
options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you
have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply
with your attorney too.
But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a
relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that
relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the
bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so
meet with one no matter what.
Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one
as soon as you can.
You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now
and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

You're welcome to inform them of your intentions to file, but that notification won't necessarily stop any of their collection efforts. Until they have an actual case number from the bankruptcy court, it's all talk that they've heard thousands of times. If they are trying to garnish wages, they'll likely continue. If they are preparing to file or in the middle of a lawsuit against you, they'll likely continue forward.

The bankruptcy filing will include a list of your creditors with their bankruptcy notification addresses. Upon the filing of your case, the court will notify your creditors, via mail or electronic notice, of the case being filed. The filing of your case automatically puts in place an Automatic Stay that prevents virtually every creditor from taking any action to collect on the debts you owe. Assuming your case goes smoothly, you should receive a discharge somewhere around 4 months after filing; however, your protection against creditors begins immediately upon filing.

Having said all this, if you haven't already, I strongly recommend you contact a qualified and experienced attorney in your area to assist you with the process of preparing and filing a bankruptcy case.

You can tell them now but since they hear that all the time they may not believe you. They'll probably ask for a case number and your attorneys name. You won't get a case number until your case is filed. Your attorney may not want you to give out her name until you've at least partially restrained her. Once you file you should definitely let them know and be prepared to give the the case number, date of filing and your attorneys contact info.

There is little or nothing gained by telling your creditors you are planning to file BK. The calls, letters and demands will likely continue. If you have a lawyer, you should ask him/her about this. No lawyer? Big mistake. Find/consult/hire a BK lawyer by clicking the Avvo tab "Find a Lawyer". Most offer a free consultation which will allow you to ask specific questions followed up by questions from the lawyer to you. Good luck.

No one cares that you are "going" to file. Everybody says they are "going" to file. The only thing that matters is when you have actually filed, case number assigned, filing fee pai, etc. If you don't know your rights, a consumer bankruptcy attorney can help you.
